Award.AwardTitle: Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for the 2016 Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium that will take place at Rice University in Houston, Texas on October 21-23, 2016. The Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium is a regional weekend meeting held annually, hosted in turn by Rice University, the University of Texas at Austin, and occasionally other institutions in the region. It is intended for the participation of around 60 people, including 25 non-local graduate students. The workshop brings together many senior mathematicians from Texas and neighboring states, who may not otherwise have an opportunity to discuss mathematics together throughout the year. Structurally the symposium consists of 7 main lectures given by nationally recognized leaders in the field, and contributed sessions (including a poster session) for advanced graduate students and participating researchers from regional universities, to present their work. This will provide graduate students with an opportunity to obtain feedback from senior faculty from other departments. The networking activities made possible by the Symposium will prove to be a valuable experience for young researchers. The Symposium encourages and financially supports participation by students, recent Ph.D. recipients, and members of groups underrepresented in mathematics. The Symposium is a forum for regional specialists in mathematical physics and related areas of analysis to become familiar with the latest problems and present their own results; in addition it introduces young mathematicians to the current state of the subject.

This year's Symposium will focus on the areas where harmonic analysis, dynamical systems theory, spectral theory, and partial differential equations intersect and interact. More information, including a list of speakers and abstracts, registration information, and an archive of the past symposium can be found at the website of the meeting:
https://www.ma.utexas.edu/users/tc/TeXAMP/TeXAMP-2016/TeXAMP-2016.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The fourth annual Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium took place October 21-23, 2016 on the campus of Rice University in Houston, TX.

The invited talks were given by Eric Carlen (Rutgers University of Maryland, Title: Functional Inequalities and Gradient Flow for Quantum Markov Semigroups), Fritz Gesztesy (Baylor University, Title: Eigenvalue counting function bounds for the Krein-von Neumann extension associated with uniformly elliptic PDEs), Michael Goldstein (University of Toronto, Title: On localization and spectrum of multi-frequency quasi-periodic operators - Report on recent progress), Anton Gorodetski (University of California Irvine, Title: Random matrix products with parameter), Philip Gressman (University of Pennsylvania, Title: Geometric Averages in Harmonic Analysis), Michael Loss (Georgia Tech, Title: Modeling thermostats using Master equations), and Lai-Sang Young (Courant Institute, Title: Nonequilibrium steady states of certain particle systems).

In addition, there were four parallel sessions in which contributed talks were presented.

Students, postdocs, and faculty from regional universities were exposed to recent research advances in Analysis and Mathematical Physics, as presented by leading researchers. Moreover they were able to meet these researchers in person and extend their network of professional contacts. In particular those that were on the job market at the time, or were about to go on the job market, managed to draw the attention of potential postdoctoral mentors to their work and their job application.

Conference participation is an important component in the education of a junior scientist, including those that do not remain in science long-term and instead move to a variety of positions in industry or government.
